name: 'Schotter', Georg Nees - Variation 01
description: Using Georg Nees 'Schotter' as a foundation, I changed the colors of the squares randomly. This made the piece look more vibrant, adding a more energetic chaos.

name: 'Schotter', Georg Nees - Variation 02
description: Changing the shape of the squares to triangles changed the feeling of the piece. It sharpens the composition while preserving the originals sense of movement and chaos.

name: 'Schotter', Georg Nees - Variation 03
description: The squares 'dance' around by changing sizes and rotate depending on their position on the canvas. The farther away from the top they are, the faster they spin. This strengthens the feeling of falling squares from the original.

name: 'Plotting', Michael Noll - Variation 01
description: Inspired by Michael Nolls 'Plotting', I changed the size of the rectangles and the colors randomly, making it look like confetti scattered randomly across the canvas.

name: 'Plotting', Michael Noll - Variation 02
description: By changing the shape of the rectangles to circles and removing the colored filling, this piece reminds of bubbles rising in water, feeling light and fluid.

name: 'Plotting', Michael Noll - Variation 03
description: The randomly generated rectanges pulse from the center outwards, looking like the canvas is breathing. The farther away they are from the center, the lighter they become, creating a hypnotic or meditational feeling.

name: Emory Dunn - Variation 01
description: Adding to Emory Dunns experiments, I animated the lines and added particles whenever a line reaches its endpoint on the circle. It then 'bounces back', creating an endless loop of little explosions, reminding of a firework.

name: Emory Dunn - Variation 02
description: For this piece, I changed the shape from a circle to a square and added a flow field. The lines still start and end at a designated point, but wander in the canvas unpredictably.

name: Colin Reid - Sound Variation
description: This sound-driven variation was inspired by Colin Reid. Each circle, defined by its random size and color, produces a tone when it appears depending on its size. They each spawn after one another to create enough room for their sound.
